column1: Before 1 January 2022, will the U.S. Senate expand the scope of matters for which a filibuster cannot be used?
column6: ['US Politics']
There is no actual modification of filibuster rules or any sort of expansion in the bill. https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/senate-bill/610/text
The time frame is the problem here, it could be that x-mas gifts are not going to be exchange in the old fart's house.

Looks like that's it: "Once he signs it, Democrats will be able to bring up and pass a debt ceiling increase with only a simple majority, instead of the normal 60 votes needed for most legislation." (Source: https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/585192-senate-passes-bill-to-avoid-filibuster-on-debt-ceiling-hike )
Oh gosh - yes - the debt ceiling! A "one time only" but I guess that still counts!

OK - Now I've moved it down to "0" because apparently the negotiations are focused more on tweaking the mechanics of the filibuster (e.g., return to something more like the talking filibuster so it's more of an effort for the minority). Apparently they are not seriously discussing a carve-out for voting rights. So in theory maybe there's a 0.3% chance but that can only be coded as "0." https://www.politico.com/news/2021/12/08/biden-filibuster-voting-rights-senate-523917?nname=politico-nightly&nid=00000170-c000-da87-af78-e185fa700000&nrid=0000016a-db08-d33a-a5ee-dfaff5c60001&nlid=2670445&fbclid=IwAR0_rSQJxUAWUuiIXP6MqNFp_JKo7PnOcDX8vtGUBjCOL745tRmM2VhxKtc
Clarification from GJO admin on a resolution flag for this question:
Ah the debt limit.
The rules changed and now this question should resolve when the vote on the debt limit occurs...which is the issue (scope) that avoids the filibuster.
Up 100%. The Senate is a mysterious place. —and sometimes people notice if they do dumb things.

EDIT: Lessons learned . . . 1) There's very helpful & generous forecasters here: Following @JMR2017--a savvy forecaster--saved my bacon because I'd still be at 2% if not for them. 2) I did insufficient research. I was surprised to learn the other day from Amy Klobuchar that there have been 160 of these carve-outs over the years. If I had realized that from the get-go, I would have asked for a clarification earlier and made significantly different forecasts. 3) I took too literally the opposition of Manchin & Sinema to changing the filibuster. I was a bit too cynical about their determination to make something work. 4) I was surprised that the Admins considered that the one-time carve-out satisfied the question. I ASSUMED (um!) that it would take a permanent change to the filibuster rules to make this question resolve as "yes". @Leifkj, @belikewater
If this happens some folk here are going to be spitting feathers at the incredulity of the questions end! Well done @Anneinak and @JMR2017 for catching the signal in all the noise.
It really looks like a done deal.
This looks like a pretty done deal, and the vote is in 2.5 hours.

What a potential upset! I hadn't been forecasting this question because the chance seemed so small. But here we are! Thanks to @Anneinak and @JMR2017 for investigating the details here. @JMR2017 writes, "10 GOP senators will need to vote with all 50 Democrats to approve the process of requiring only a simple majority of support on the actual legislation to raise the debt limit. Nobody is labeling this a change to the filibuster but that's what is going to happen when the Senate votes for a one time change to the rules so that the filibuster doesn't apply to the debt limit. A rose is a rose by any other name."
Based on the clarity provided to @Anneinak , thanks!
vat is this shit.
US politics makes my head spin....I'd been ready to write this one off. Then a one time exception, never been considered before, falls in bounds and the question turns on the proverbial dime.
GJ Admin Clarifications said: Thank you for your inquiry. The answer to your question is yes, a one-time exception would count.
@Anneinak 10 GOP senators will need to vote with all 50 Democrats to approve the process of requiring only a simple majority of support on the actual legislation to raise the debt limit.
House approves debt limit framework that will allow it to pass Senate with 51 votes
A debt limit carve out would count.
its part of policy to be worked on eventually but its not priority for this adminitration, dealing with sinema and mcarthy filibuster can sit on backburner

Since there is very likely a majority against changing the filibuster in the current senate (at least every Republican and likely Senators Manchin and Sinema), the filibuster will likely not be changed. While the Democratic senators opposed might be persuaded to change their minds for limited purposes, there does not seem to be any high-profile legislation coming up in December which would justify such an effort.
No, IF it happens it certainly won’t be this year.
Down 5% for passage of time and the USG not turning out the lights.
Passage of time.
Ticking up a bit because the timing of the debt ceiling debate in December and reconciliation in senate on BBB
Way back down - Sinema recently stated categorically she was opposed; apparently both she and Manchin have been showered with campaign contributions by corporate groups normally allied with the GOP.

The debt is coming up Dec 3 and Republicans have vowed not to raise it. Might get Sinema and Manchin on board for that change but in general they say no. After decades of opposing changing the filibuster rule, Biden, on Oct. 21, said he now supports efforts to “fundamentally alter” it. “Two key Senate Democrats – Joe Manchin and Kyrsten Sinema – adamantly oppose such, and their opposition dooms any attempts.”

We're starting to get into the part of the year when the Senate calendar is very lacy--full of holes for holidays--and there's not much time left for legislation. Given that the BBB bill is still in the hopper, I don't think there will be time or energy for something like a rules change.
The Guardian is drivel: https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/nov/06/kyrsten-sinema-filibuster-betrayed-arizona-voting-rights

(no change) One way to look at the VA gov race is that the D candidate picked the wrong subjects/approach (school busing in the past comes to mind as a comparison class). If anything, I'd presume the D's will do almost anything to show some progress related to "being in the majority" before they are possibly not. The Senate voting bill should actually pass the giggle test (except some of those people on some networks). A carve-out is not hard to sell; a carve out to expand spending is a bit harder, but then who got most of the tax cuts under 45? (Wonder how many in the US would have a general idea.)
-1 on passage of time
Whatever plausibility this had is about over and done with

Inching this up from 30 to 35%, as Sen. Warner has announced he would vote to carve out voting rights: https://www.politico.com/video/2021/10/27/warner-on-filibuster-i-would-carve-out-an-exception-around-voting-rights-387439 He had been considered a likely hold out. Similarly, Sen. King and Sen. Shaheen have voiced support for a carve out, so there's some movement. However, we still know Manchin and Sinema may still stay dug in, so I'm not going over 50% yet, until I hear some fresh news from them.

The repeated failure to get a voting rights bill onto the Senate floor has upped the pressure to create a carve out, but I don't see signs that Manchin or Sinema are having a change of heart about carve-outs. I still think that the most likely outcome is a change to a talking filibuster which won't satisfy this question.
Time

I'm inching this up from 25 - 30%. As I said recently, I still see the odds less than 50-50, but there is so much at stake for the Dem's chances in 2022 and 2024, and there's enough "chatter" filtering into the media that I don't see it as impossible, either. Here's an update that appeared in today's Washington Post about Sen. King and Sen. Tester (who had been leaning against any reform) now leaning in favor: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2021/10/21/manchin-republicans-end-filibuster/
If Manchin was going to budge on this it would have happened already. The closer you get to the midterms the less sense it makes.

Edging this up slightly - the Senate test vote on the Freedom To Vote Act yesterday went as expected. Schumer voted "no" as a procedural manoever to be able to bring it back up for reconsideration a bit later. Next week he will bring up the related John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act which is likely to go thru the same motions. Then - we don't know because Dem leadership is being extremely tight-lipped, but given the stakes if neither bill can be passed (think: midterms and what Dem prospects would look like with versus without the voting rights bills enacted) the hope is that Manchin will indeed go along with a filibuster-carve-out for voting rights. So while I don't want to get my hopes up (and don't assess the odds as being higher than 50%), I also don't think the odds are quite as dismal as other people assume. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/voting-rights-manchin-senate/2021/10/20/caba5168-31a6-11ec-a1e5-07223c50280a_story.html
(no change) The "Freedom to Vote Act" is a wild card.
No change. I'd normally go a bit down, but the debt ceiling debacle has spooked me.
Doesn't appear to be the votes for this to occur.

So McConnell agreed to pause between now and December 3rd. And then what? In the after math, McConnell sends a letter to President Biden saying he'll never agree again to raise the debt ceiling, blaming Schumer for rubbing his nose in it. https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/576039-in-blistering-letter-to-biden-mcconnell-vows-gop-wont-help-raise-debt-ceiling-in
Down 5% on (imperfect) deal.
With the McConnell deal, I see no reason Manchin would give in on changing filibuster.

Hmmm - Sen. McConnell really REALLY does not want to give Sen. Manchin an excuse to vote for any change in the filibuster - I'm pretty sure that's why he agreed to the "compromise" on a very short-term increase in the debt ceiling lasting to December. By then, it's practically too late for the Senate to pass the Freedom To Vote Act in time for it to be effective for the 2022 midterms. So I'm dropping my assessment back down again (probably still biased by wishful thinking).
Finally joining the crowd.

Right back down again with the apparent preference in Dem circles to take a fairly paltry "offer" of a temporary solution rather than go with the big, bold move of pulling in the wayward senators and pulling McConnels teeth with a narrow carve out of the filibuster for Debt Ceiling relief.
Back down 5% on purported deal.
https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/575631-democrats-signal-they-will-accept-mcconnell-offer

Looks like McConnell agreed to push the debt limit to December 1. If the agreement sticks, no need for the filibuster carve out on debt yet. What about voting rights which Democrats really need? My forecast is based on a Spring boil of the pressure cooker regarding the filibuster.
The debt ceiling comment opens up new ground.
They could go for it. It would be the last time but that might be why they do it now, while they can.,
Biden has suggested they may carve out the debt ceiling from the filibuster: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/05/us/politics/debt-ceiling-filibuster-biden.html?referringSource=articleShare
Up 10%. Nice economy you have here, wouldn't want anything to happen to it would you?
Manchin denying for now. Nuclear option increasingly being floated. https://www.bloomberg.com/?sref=i2Bc5OtW

Coming up temporarily on this from The Current Incumbent, who may have forgotten that he no longer has a vote in the Senate, either as a member or a tie-breaker: https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-senate-democrats-plan-debt-limit-vote-after-biden-hints-filibuster-could-go-2021-10-06/

Up a little when considering RECENT historical precedent (2010 - 2021) base rate that sees a carve out made to the filibuster rules every time power in the senate changes hands. Dems (cautious, hesitant and polite) seem to make the change before they loose power, Reps (with far fewer poops given) make changes shortly after they've taken power to maximise their impact. With a rough 2022 on the horizon for Dems a very shallow data set of recent trends suggests, at a base rate level of analysis, this would not be outside the frame in this moment.
Don't believe it very likely that McConnel (with all his money donners) is actually going to allow the US to default on its debts. The implications to those he cares most about don't seem to add up.

outside view (historic precedent): This has only happened twice in recent history, one by each party and only when the controlling party is desperate to do something, such as the democrats now... Inside View: The dept ceiling is the only thing I can see Manchin or Sinema folding to. It seams the GOP is willing to take us over the edge and the question is how the Dems "do it on their own". Here are my thoughts on the options to resolve this crisis: - Reconciliation (separate from BBB) - 75% (simple/least "offensive" to moderates) - this will decrease as we near the cliff - Reconciliation (with BBB) - 5% (negotiations will take too long) - Change Filibuster - 15% - GOP folds under threat of change to filibuster - 5%
Moving from 5% for awhile … Till debt limit is passed. https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/biden-senate-filibuster-change-on-debt-a-real-possibility/ar-AAPb2b5

Up 5% for a few days. Anyone who thinks they have control of the various legislative issues is a bit naive. In the case of JB, "don't throw me in the briar patch?" (yes I realize the reference in no longer PC FWIW).

With this latest vote [1] it almost seems like Republicans are trying to force the Democrats into putting a carve out into the Filibuster for certain key voting issues, perhaps as part of a a long term strategy to better empower themselves as they become more and more the "minority rule" party?

I found this [1] quite convincing from a purely mechanical point of view (i.e. taking the political motivations and machinations out for a second) and, when putting these human factors back into the equation, the barriers to a carve out for an existential issue like voting rights seem hard but also comparatively thin (2 Senators with room to move from their current positions if provided suitable reason, incentive, top cover and "alternative meat" to save their reputations).

Kyrsten Sinema Faces No Confidence Threat From Arizona Dems Over Filibuster - Newsweek https://www.newsweek.com/kyrsten-sinema-faces-no-confidence-threat-arizona-dems-over-filibuster-1632771 Sun, 26 Sep 2021 10:36:52 GMT f863571e970ab8e35e1280756d876006
The prospects of this happening are complicated... not likely, but not negligible. Let's see how the stalemate plays out...

Based on what I read in this article about Biden promising to bring Manchin & Sinema around: https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/biden-filibuster-voting-rights-corruption-manchin-sinema-1224269/
https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/biden-filibuster-voting-rights-corruption-manchin-sinema-1224269/
No change.
Matching doesn't want to. Isn't necessary to pass budget bills. Voting rights not worth the political capital.

Given what's at stake, and the pressure coming to bear on Manchin (who is a co-author and co-sponsor of the new Freedom to Vote Act), I would assess that the prospects for SOME kind of filibuster reform may be nearing 50%. While it's still possible that other forms of filibuster reform might be enacted (e.g., returning to the classic "talking filibuster"), the Washington Post article by Normans Ornstein and Eisen (that I posted last week) is getting picked up in chatter (e.g., I attended a rally at the Capitol yesterday where Sens Klobuchar, Merkley, Padilla and Van Hollen all spoke). Sen. Van Hollen, in particular was comparing the importance of voting rights to budget reconciliation. Most of what I'm hearing is about a carve-out for voting rights, which would fall within the definition of the question. So my rough assessment is now about one third.

Edging this back up again - carve out for voting rights would count for the question; other versions of reform probably not, but things may be moving in that direction. https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2021/09/13/filibuster-senate-voting-rights-democrats/
Not happening, because of one Senator, you can guess who.
No change
https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/biden-filibuster-voting-rights-corruption-manchin-sinema-1224269/

Leaked donor calls to moderates reassure there are enough adults in the room on this topic, it’s for show like student debt forgiveness, taxing unrealized gains and all the other things that will never happen.
Enough Democratic senators are opposed to block. The President is opposed. Both may change but it seems unlikely before 1 Jan 22.
https://www.reuters.com/world/us/filibuster-imperils-pelosis-abortion-bill-us-senate-klobuchar-2021-09-05/
Passage of time

(no change) An NPR segment (sorry too lazy to look it up) with a former (acting?) US Solicitor General observed that a federal statute over-ruling the Texas (and other state's) abortion laws would be in a different category and should not be subject to Senate filibuster. It seemed a stretch, but the US has lots of lawyers with lots of opinions.
If manchin isn’t willing to do 3.5 tln budget, he’s not willing to change the filibuster rules.

In other forecasts I've found myself to be over confident as to the ability (and even the will) for Dems to get big, meaningful and impactful things done to Legislation with the current balance of power. Those from the US with a regular eye on politics will likely be smiling knowingly at my naiveite at this point!
No change
No change
Nope, not happening out of fear of losing the Senate next year.
They won't spend the political capital. Things are going their way now.
Without Manchin on board, it's hard to see this happening for the remainder of the year

I think this is very unlikely at the moment. I'm open to the filibuster becoming a more salient issue in time, but currently with Afghanistan I think the filibuster is at the back of people's minds. Clyburn coming out and saying voting rights should not be stopped by the filibuster shows there is some support from high ranking Dems to change it, but while Biden is opposed to ending/limiting it I don't think anything will happen.
Adjusting up a little following the Afghan withdrawal fiasco.

McConnell voted to allow debate on the infrastructure bill. I think that part of his reason for doing so was to deflate the "kill-the-filibuster" balloon. Therefore, it looks like the infrastructure bill will pass, and some will point to as proof that bipartisanship is possible.
-3 passage of time lack of news.
With passage of an infrastructure bill looking more possible, the pressure for changes to the filibuster rules is decreased.

The Current Divide between Democrats and Republicans WARRANT it . Filibuster has to go or be restricted . Democracy is run based on the rule of Simple Majority ... in excess of 50% ... and not 67% being the requirement .

Ugh. https://www.forbes.com/sites/andrewsolender/2021/07/15/forget-the-filibuster-manchin-rejects-voting-rights-carve-out-after-meeting-with-texas-democrats/?sh=59d0554f7cd4&fbclid=IwAR0OYsk-MdnD27uzpEQVYiwRUkBbIgMpZ891CIFx_yBsKmZvRXp5QRFDm_o

More red herrings: - https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/jul/13/house-democrats-senate-filibuster-exception-voting-rights - https://eu.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2021/07/13/biden-voting-rights-drive-push-filibuster-exception/7951158002/ - https://eu.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2021/06/27/filibuster-blocks-progress-minimum-wage-voter-suppression/7781249002/

I'm inching this up primarily because it was proposed by Rep. Clyburn to expand to include voting rights. I still think it's unlikely overall, if for no other reason than many Senators (not just Manchin and Sinema) would be justifiably anxious that the GOP could turn the tables and ram voter suppression measures through Congress if they got the opportunity. I'm somewhat more hopeful that they might pass a reform to return the filibuster to something more like the classic "talking filibuster", but that would not fulfill the criteria for this question. We should know by the end of September. If nothing happens by then, it is extremely unlikely to happen during the last quarter, because it would really be too late to enact voting rights reform in time for the 2022 mid-terms. (And the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act could conceivably be passed, and perhaps more likely to be passed in early 2022 - it would also require filibuster reform but the would be past the deadline of the question).

With "the nuclear option" only requiring a quorum of Democrats to vote on it, and with Voting Rights being an existential issue for both sides to wrestle with, this question's resolution as a "yes" (with "Clyburn's carve out" being the most rational and likely way in which that resolution could occur [1]) seems to sit on a very small number of politician's shoulders (and as such feels in no way as certain as the crowd appear to be feeling at this moment).
Clyburn's "carve out " would count. But I don't think that all Democrats will support that in this time frame.
Error: I misread this question. 10 Republicans will not say yes.
No. You will not get 10 Republicans to say yes.
@fisherdbus links a good article describing how it's just not Manchin & Sinema who are unenthusiastic about ditching the filibuster @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1303650
https://apnews.com/article/senators-to-watch-as-democrats-debate-changing-filibuster-a4b3b1a7611a715f85dc904e5bab7d3e
Down 5% considering how high I've been earlier.
https://thehill.com/opinion/white-house/556133-democrats-use-of-congressional-review-act-puts-filibuster-debate-in-new?rl=1
AKA, the votes aren't there.

Manchin's surprise move into the Dem fold on last nights vote is quite telling as to where he finds himself when chips are down (where his voting record shows he is in no way averse to voting against his party and with Republicans when he feels able to [1]). Rep obstruction is in no way a surprise and confirms the premise that this is an existential issue for both sides (as it defines the power play for the mid terms and the next presidential election cycle).

I'm increasing my odds only slightly on the basis of all the chatter about filibuster reform in association with the voting rights legislation. I still think the more likely scenario may favor a return to the something more like the classic "talking filibuster" (I might give that roughly 50% odds) and/or changing the threshold for cloture from 60 to 55 (I'd give that a roughly 10% chance on its own), but a carve-out for voting rights is still being discussed (but I don't think it would be the preferred reform by Manchin or even Schumer, since the consequences of the GOP turning tables if they win control of the Senate would be dire).
I was just dead wrong on this one.
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/17/opinion/joe-manchin-filibuster-voting-rights.html
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/17/opinion/joe-manchin-filibuster-voting-rights.html

Staying at 8%, Manchin apparently said he's considering lowering the threshold to 55 votes. My guess is that wouldn't result in positive resolution for this question though. But changes to the filibuster don't seem off the table. Overall seems unlikely though.
Down 10% for passage of time. Also Manchin taking the heat, but others in the wing not ready to make a significant change.
Democrats, Converted to Filibuster Foes, Are Set to Force the Issue - The New York Times https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/04/us/democrats-filibuster-senate.html Tue, 08 Jun 2021 07:00:00 GMT
https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/12/politics/joe-manchin-analysis/index.html
Seems increasingly unlikely, and recent news about Jacky Rosen opposing eliminating it makes it seem like more than just Manchin and Sinema want to keep it. -7

On PBS news last night I heard Amy Klobuchar say that she thinks Manchin will go for a "standing" filibuster. That change might make imposition of a filibuster a less common practice, but I do not think it will cause this question to resolve as "yes" UNLESS the change ALSO involves expanding the scope of matters for which a filibuster cannot be used.
Dropping a little with more effusive comments from Manchin that are arguably nailing his feet to the floor on this (or restabilising his stance to manage all expectations). [1]

Joe Manchin: Why I'm voting against the For the People Act https://www.wvgazettemail.com/opinion/op_ed_commentaries/joe-manchin-why-im-voting-against-the-for-the-people-act/article_c7eb2551-a500-5f77-aa37-2e42d0af870f.html Jun 6, 2021
Manchin is staying strong in his opposition to any modifications to the filibuster.
The filibuster won't be challenged for the purpose of passing voting right changes because Manchin has announced that he will not vote for the We the People bill.

Now we have the Kyrsten Sinema/ John Cornyn road show talking up bipolarship. What's up with that? I'm not entirely sure but she is digging in on how great the filibuster is for keeping things the way they are calling that bipartisanship. Staying low at 0.
After @Anneinak posted her update (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1285802) I wrestled for 24 hours with how the parliamentarians verdict could influence this one.

Raising probability estimate since there is a lot of strong sentiment expressed on social media, if Manchin reverses, maybe Sinema will too, although she seems obstinate. [https://thehill.com/homenews/556587-sinema-defends-filibuster-sparking-progressive-fury]
@Mark_T continues to make good arguments that Manchin will reverse his stance.

Moving up slightly with the latest Republican blocking of the Jan 6 commission and Manchin's (likely stage manged) surprise and appal at seeing his GOP counterparts vote in an entirely predictable "three-line whip". [1]
Down 5% for passage of time. 46 may charter a bipartisan Jan 6 panel and there are signs of some token infrastructure compromise. HB 1 probably won't tip the scales.
No signs on the horizon

Doing away with the filibuster would allow a bill to pass the Senate even though it is opposed by Senators representing almost 10% of the US population. What would become of democracy if mere 90% support could pass any old piece of legislation?
Dropping 5% for passage of time.

They'll likely change it to require physical standing/speaking or a minimum quorum to sustain before going full nuclear, and even then only after lots of obstructionism. Likely after the midterms if ever.
No change
Dropping on time and the fact that rhetoric seems to be moving away from it again.
And so it begins...
https://www.politico.com/newsletters/politico-nightly/2021/05/03/the-filibuster-isnt-stopping-senate-dems-492702

I don't take Joe Manchin's rejection of filibuster reform at face value. He often says no before he says yes. [1] However, now that the Covid relief bill passed via reconciliation, Biden seems content to negotiate with Senate Republicans. [2]

Passage of time, plus increasing clarity for Manchin's dedication to Senate rules, plus the fact that dems have already pushed through a lot of what they want, plus parlimentarian's ruling that they can use reconciliation more than initially thought.
Moving up to a middle ground modified position having slept on it and reviewed previous rationales.

A good and worthy challenge from @Anneinak, and with Manchin doubling down on his current position (https://www.forbes.com/sites/andrewsolender/2021/04/22/aint-gonna-happen-manchin-scoffs-at-latest-attempt-to-end-filibuster/?sh=5a4300ff28f1) and no overt mention of voting rights in Biden's address I'm willing to drop.

I note that most of the time when people talk about the filibuster, they talk about the # of votes it takes to filibuster or break a filibuster. However, this question asks about expanding the "scope of matters", so if the Senate voted to change the filibuster rules to 55 votes but left unchanged the matters which could be filibustered, this question would still resolve as "No"!
https://www.forbes.com/sites/andrewsolender/2021/04/22/aint-gonna-happen-manchin-scoffs-at-latest-attempt-to-end-filibuster/?sh=5a4300ff28f1
Jk just heard him mention voting rights.
No mention of voting rights in Biden's speech makes this pretty unlikely so long as nothing dramatic happens.
As I've acquired better and better models around this, my probability has been going lower and lower. In particular, I now think that Manchin "is for real"

For now, the probability is pretty low as result of Manchin's statements on the matter, however he has a tendency to bend under pressure after he receives something in exchange. Additionally, it depends a lot on if he has decided to seek re-election or that he realizes his changes of re-election are on the decline. Another key test point is going to be the infrastructure bill. Without significant concessions to the Republicans, sixty votes seems highly unlikely. A good pile of pork for West Virginia might sway Manchin. Also, Sinema should be watched. Even though she is not up for re-election for another three years, her rapidly declining public opinion may move her towards more publicly opposing any changes to the filibuster.
Manchins statement draws a fairly firm red line under his position at this moment although I note his conditional caveat that (I paraphrase) ‘Republicans need to grow up’.
This is a late response to the Manchin op ed.
(no change) Interesting WVa and AZ angle:
Not by the end of this year

Many possibilities - I still think the biggest odds would be in favor of a reform that increased the "cost" to the minority party to execute a filibuster (which, on its own, would not fulfill the requirements of the question, although I think it would represent significant progress). Sen. Manchin's OpEd in the Washington Post had sounded categorical against any significant reform, but the pundits are saying "Never say never" and suggesting that he was focused primarily on the infrastructure bill(s). But I'm keeping my eye on HR1/S1 and the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement bill. Manchin has definitely signaled that he favors picking apart S1 and trying to encourage GOP to support one or two elements within it (e.g., early voting, the Native American Voting Rights Act, election security and/or transparency in campaign finance). But if (as I suspect) there are not 10 GOP Senators who can get on board any of those provisions, then I can envision Manchin making a "heroic" decision to add "voting rights" to the category of items that should not be subject to a filibuster. Having done more research, I am now significantly more confident a filibuster change will happen with a Democratic majority in the Senate. Each party has made a change to the filibuster after gaining control in the last 2 swings (2013 and 2017), so the recent precedence in there. Ongoing protests continue to provide pressure from below while support from key figures provides it from above. More importantly, however, it appears the American people are reaching a breaking point with platitudes from politicians. Many are now demanding more than prayers and investigations, they are demanding actual, substantive change. This is one of the easiest ways to achieve a tangible result to point to with supporters without sticking your neck out politically. On top of this, Democrats have a ton of legislative proposals that have been killed in the Senate in large part due to the filibuster and are therefore further incentivized to pass this particular piece of legislation quickly once they win the Senate. Not doing so would risk a stalemate in their first years in charge which could drive voters pack to the GOP. Politically speaking, if the Dems win the Senate, this move just makes sense

New forecast reflects the fact that some Democratic senators may be unlikely to support further limiting the filibuster, even narrowly, and that there is still uncertainty in Democrats winning a majority. A simple majority is required to change the rules that would end the filibuster, but the odds of both Democrats winning a senate majority and of 51 or more of those Democratic senators wanting to eliminate the filibuster seems pretty low. The filibuster is a check on the majority, and I think Democrats in the Senate would be hesitant to change that rule and be on the receiving end of that change in later years. Joe Biden has seemed reluctant to support ending the filibuster as well. It's possible, but seems unlikely.

The current saga of filibuster reform began in 1975 when the number of votes needed to pass a cloture motion was reduced to 60. Since that time, five other substantive revisions have occurred in 1979, 1986, 2013 and 2017 respectively. This leaves us with an average of some kind of reform every nine years. As can been seen from a brief glance at the dates however, this doesn’t present a full picture. The Senate tends to go through phases where it fits the majority party’s interest to alter procedure for partisan reasons and when these periods occur the usually last about 4 years (1975-9, 2013-7) but can go as long as 7 (1979-1986). [1] By this logic, 2021 seems like it might be the time for the upper chamber to take a look at its rulebook again.

I think there is about a 65% chance that the Democrats win the Senate and the Presidency. Conditional on that, I thinkh tere's roughly 2/3 odds of them agreeing to remove the filibuster in order to pass important legislation (that can't be done through budget reconciliation).

I'm betting on Democrats winning a majority in the Senate. The next Congress faces pressing issues --the ECONOMY first and foremost, voting rights, civil rights, healthcare and police reform... These are some of the issues demanding attention for which Republicans and Democrats widely disagree. As so much has gone backwards with Republicans in charge, the new President (my other bet) has to show immediate progress for a restless and in many cases hurting and damaged public. There should be zero tolerance among Democrats for political dithering and obstruction from the likes of Mitch McConnell, et al. There ought to be quite a bit of pent up anger/demand to do major things if not simply to reverse some of the damage done over the last 4 years. I expect that getting rid of the filibuster or amending how it cannot be applied will need to happen fairly quickly unless Republicans completely change their stripes and decide that they must "get along" in a post Trump era.
Further explanation and reply to comments:

When the Republicans eliminated the filibuster for SC nominations, that was purely to prevent their nominee from being blocked, it does not follow that they will aggressively seek to reduce the filibuster's reach, especially given the rising chances that they lose their Senate majority. Democrats may want to push this through but it does not seem to be a major priority and again, the filibuster serves a purpose: it serves to slow things down when you don't have the votes to vote down a bill and I'm not sure that's a power that either party will want to limit. I'll "intuit" a number and say there's a slither of a chance: 15%.

I'm cautiously optimistic that yes, by January 1, 2022, the Senate will expand the scope of matters for which filibuster cannot be used. I expect that today's crises will continue to unfold, putting public pressure on Congress to legislate equity and justice matters that won't find a place in the budget reconciliation process. Whether the majority is R or D, it'll be a narrow majority with a minority that's ready to fight for every inch. The nuclear option happened twice in the last decade. In 2013 Senator Reid and the Democrats excluded executive branch nominations and Federal court appointments. In 2017 Senator McConnell led Republicans to extend the exclusion to Supreme Court Justices, ending debate on the nomination of Gorsuch. The procedural tactic of voting to end filibuster on a matter is becoming normalized, and there will be great pressure to end it for certain legislative matters. I assign a modest 59% to this prediction because I expect the Democrats to take the Senate by only 2 to 4 seats, and while that's enough to invoke the nuclear option, not all Democrats are on board so it will take time for the party to negotiate. I'm sleepy that it will get done before 2022, but the pressure crisis may have the last word.
The Republicans position will be either a weak majority or a strong minority after November. They will not want to cede this power to the Democarts and now McConnell controls the Senate

I'm revising my numbers for Senate Dems +6 significantly upward:

The 2013 and 2017 filibuster changes applied only to nominations and did not remove the ability to filibuster so much as reduce the 60/40 rule to a simple majority. Republicans have no pending legislation and are unlikely to put forward any that may benefit from the updated filibuster and, moreover, will be wary of switching the requirements in case the Democrats ever obtain a majority. If anything, it is more likely they will remove the ability to filibuster from the nomination process to make confirmations and appointments easier in the coming months, but even that is unlikely given the risk of Democratic control. I give it about a 35% chance the Democrats win the Senate, in which case there is a good chance they remove the filibuster from key legislation, and around a 3% chance the Republicans remove the filibuster for nominations if they do maintain control. Results: 38%

If any progressive legislative priorities are to become law -- Medicare for All is the big one but also climate change, gun safety, voting rights, etc -- then the filibuster must end. That Obama is floating the idea (https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/07/why-senate-filibuster-could-be-gone-2021/614278/) and Biden isn't immediately ruling it out (https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/14/joe-biden-2020-filibuster-360587) means that Senate institutionalist are no longer blocking filibuster reform. See also Chris Coons (https://www.vox.com/2020/6/24/21300514/chris-coons-filibuster-reform-senate-nuclear-option).
